narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I learned to be a leader and to critically think about the ways I could use theoretical knowledge in a practical way.
Several different forms of leadership in the field of reforming education.

Before taking this course, I had a pretty much fully formed opinion about what the problems in education are and, generally, what people currently involved in public education need to do to solve them; however, after taking this course, I learned that there are so many possible ways to "reform" education and that perhaps the question is not which one is the right way, but rather how can ideas from each model be synthesized to offer the best possible educational experience to children? 

I loved that this class was based on case studies of particular districts, schools, and states, so I became a lot better at identifying the practices that actually function to improve learning versus those that just look good on paper.
An understanding of the barriers to improvement and change in the American education system. Theories of Leadership and Institutional Change.

I learned about a number of specific cases mostly from the past 20 years of attempts at educational reform, and I learned more generally about the different possible policy levers to create educational change.  I learned all about the benefits and drawbacks to different approaches.
I learned about modern problems with education and different types of solutions.
Survey of various specific attempts to implement education reform

I learned so much from this course, probably one of the most informative and life changing classes at Yale for me. I had never taken an EDST course before so I was really learning a lot of the concepts for the first time regarding leadership in schools, logistics of change, models and case studies of education reform, the insidious forces behind the achievement and opportunity gap, etc.

I learned a lot about the various levers of change in the American education system and the role that leadership plays in getting things done (or preventing things from getting done). It was interesting learning about how theories of leadership can account for the actions of individuals in the education system and how those actions interacted with various components of the system to produce the end result.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: This class is perfect. Genuinely. Maybe not a growth mindset that Professor Lemons would like but I would not change anything about the course.

Strengths: incredibly engaging seminar! All of the readings were interesting and facilitated meaningful discussion during class. This truly is a class where you learn from your peers as much as you do from the readings or professor.

This is an amazing course. The biggest strength of this course is that you are engaged 100% of the time. Professor Lemons often cold-called us (but not in a way that was intimidating), made sure to ask for everyone's opinion, had us role-play, and facilitated a variety of activities using breakout rooms. The cases and articles that Professor Lemons assigned us to read were thought-provoking and always left me with questions, and I genuinely looked forward to our once-weekly seminars where peers would share their thoughts on the case and Professor Lemons would give his own take.

Another important aspect of this course was a group project where we essentially got to choose whatever education-related problem we wanted and research it/come up with a proposal. Throughout the semester, you turn in chunks of the project in the form of diagrams and memos, and at the end of the semester, there is a symposium where Professor Lemons invites many important stakeholders of education in Connecticut (i.e. superintendents and the commissioner of education) and all the groups present their findings and proposal and receive feedback from the audience. I had such a great time working with my group, and Professor Lemons always gave us great feedback that encouraged us to look at our problem from a different angle. I honestly have nothing negative to say about this course.
Professor Lemons is outstanding: professional, compassionate, and enthusiastic.

This course is fantastic.  I especially like how the work was spread throughout the semester with the case analysis and the group project.  The only small improvement would be to spend less time on logistics in each class so that we could explore the cases in even greater depth.
This course's greatest strength is Professor Lemons, who breathes life into the material. This class was one of the best I've ever taken at Yale.

The course is centered on examining real world applications of education reform policies, which was an incredibly refreshing departure from how Yale classes normally go (too theory heavy w/o consideration of implementation and consequences). The biggest strength of the class, however, was Professor Lemons who is an absolute gem.

Strengths: great professor, lively class discussion, a very accepting and kind cohort of classmates, group project (surprisingly!) and the readings were some of the most interesting I've ever had 
Weaknesses: the online format was really difficult and sad especially for such an interactive class

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: This class was great at adapting to the virtual format, I did not feel stunted or limited by being on Zoom. I was constantly engaged and enjoyed attending the class.

The several breakout room discussions really really helpful. In most classes, I think breakout rooms are not done very well, with everyone very eager to leave them, but that was not the case with this class. Prof Lemons always provided good prompts for discussion and also created an environment where we all felt like we could contribute.

Breakout rooms worked really well for this course. Everyone in the class was, of course, genuinely really passionate about education, so breakout rooms allowed for thoughtful conversation and idea-sharing.
The use of breakout rooms and non-intimidating cold calls was excellent!  This course worked quite well virtually.
Professor Lemons fostered a close, tight-knit community even over Zoom, through group discussions and through directly calling on students. It was very successful.
Professor Lemons clearly put a ton of thought into how community could thrive and class discussion could remain vibrant in an online space. It worked well over Zoom

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I would recommend this to any student. Regardless of one's experience with education, there is so much to gain out of taking this course. The level of intellectual challenge was oftentimes intense, but never threatening. I came to class with varied levels of preparedness, but always knew that Professor Lemons and my peers would support me. It was truly a magical class; one of my favorites at Yale by far.

Absolutely! Everyone should take this course, especially Ed Studies scholars. You learn so much about leadership in education but also about yourself and what skills you may need to work on to better your own abilities as a leader and an advocate in the field of education.

Absoutely. Professor Lemons is an absolutely amazing instructor and brings so much experience to this course. The case studies and discussions really challenge you to think critically about education as it stands now and opens the door to explore endless possibilities for how it can be improved.
Yes
YES, professor lemons is AMAZING.
Yes, if you're willing to put in the work, you'll come out of the class having gathered a substantial sum of knowledge on American education, and a better understanding of yourself as a person!
Absolutely; anyone interested in creating change in education and/or becoming a better leader would benefit greatly from this class!
Absolutely - one of the best classes I've ever taken.

Absolutely. Excellent class that forces you to truly assess previous attempts at education reform from leaders who've been through places like Yale and learned all the theory we have. The class allows you to determine how those ideals and theories actually play out when applied.
Yes, it was the most formative class I've taken at Yale.
